{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3548321,"name":"Gabriel McMahon","username":"G-8000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/g-8000/{size}/253453_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T16:42:40.120Z","cooked":"

My team is new to building elevators and we are using the WCP cascade elevator with 2 extra stages. We assembled it fully and were doing programming testing on it as well as playing some defense throughout our competition. When we felt the strings they were loose on the outside length but tight on the inside length. I feel as though the building documentation from WCP was brief on the description for the process of tying the string and continued maintenance.
I would highly appreciate if someone who has done this properly would share some info or photos on how to properly tie the string and maintain it over a competition. A video would be even more helpful. Thank you!

Make sure you tension the ratchets for all the string loops before tightening the clamping plates. That what usally causes it in my experience, but some retenesioning might be needed as stuff starts to settle and wear in

We’re using the exact same elevator this year and have had good results. Can you send some pictures? Also, can you define outside vs inside? Are different strings loose and tight, or are different sections of the same string loose and tight?

This is tentatively the solution to our problem! We tightened the plates, then tensioned which now I realize does not make a ton of sense. I will try to check tonight if this works for us. Additionally, if it began to loosen would you undo the clamping plates, then tension?

I believe our issue was installing the plates before we tensioned the rope. If you remember how you tied the rope at the tensioning point that would be very helpful becuase we were having some trouble with that!

Yes, any time you tension one of the ratchets you must undo the clamping plate

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-03-05T17:30:36.264Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":87,"readers_count":86,"score":32.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":494355,"topic_slug":"help-needed-rigging-wcp-3-stage-elevator","display_username":"Will C","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":67177,"username":"G-8000","name":"Gabriel McMahon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/g-8000/{size}/253453_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66211,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design"},"post_url":"/t/help-needed-rigging-wcp-3-stage-elevator/494355/6","custom_user_title":"3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design","reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3548390,"name":"Will C","username":"Suppdog222","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/suppdog222/{size}/256515_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T17:42:17.753Z","cooked":"

We put one end through the hole in the hex shaft and tied a knot to prevent it from pulling back through, then ran the other end through the pulleys and tied it to the string. Couldn’t tell you the exact type of knot though, we just found a kid on the team that was an eagle scout and had him tie a knot

We learned the hard way if you’re using dyneema rope that you should stretch out the rope prior to installing and running it on your robot. We tied 50 lb weights to the bottom of ours and elevated them for a couple of days to evenly stretch out the rope, if not the tension will just release over time. Has worked well for us thus far!
